prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving high redshift sub-mm sources in the WHDF
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to measure the angular size of 15 sub-mm sources already detected using APEX LABOCA. The observations use ALMA band 7 and the C34-4 configuration to obtain observations with an angular resolution of 0."1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to observe in the same 850 micron (band 7), that we observed with LABOCA, such that we know the precise source flux and the S/N that we will achieve in our ALMA exposures. We propose to observe with the ALMA extended array in the C36-6 configuration to achieve 0.''1 resolution.
We show the coords and other parameters for each of the sources in Table 1 of our proposal. The positions for the WHDF EVLA detected sources and the ALESS sources are good to sub-arcsecond accuracy. The seven remaining unidentified WHDF sources have positions good to ~10'' from the LABOCA observations (Bielby et al 2011) and so will easily be detected within the ALMA primary beam-width, given our conservative exposure times proposed for the ALMA observations as described next.
Our faintest source has a flux of 3.2 mJy. For an extended source of ~1.5kpc, and our resolution scale of 0.''1 (~0.5kpc), this would give a mean flux per spatial resolution element of ~0.3mJy. Using the sensitivity calculator, we find that we can reach a 3-sigma sensitivity of 0.3 mJy per resolution element given a 5 min integration time with the C36-6 configuration (345 GHz observing frequency, 7.5 GHz bandwidth and default water vapour settings). The result is approximately the same for both our fields, with the Dec=-27deg field giving marginally better results. So should a source prove to show a multiplicity of up to a factor of 10X, these observations will still make positive detections of the component contributing sources.
Alternatively, assuming a single point source, our faintest target at 3.2 mJy would have S/N~30.
For all 15 targets, we therefore require a total integration time of approximately 75 mins (excluding overheads, calibrations etc).
We request low-resolution continuum measurements of the targets, and therefore require no spectral mapping of the sources.

We request 0.1 arcsec ALMA resolution in order to achieve 0.5kpc/h resolution in a z~2 SMG. This resolution is crucial because it represents the smallest size that a dust torus around an AGN nucleus can be if it is to produce the ~35K dust temperatures shown by SMGs. Thus any SMGs that are still unresolved at this resolution are likely to be AGN powered. If they are well resolved at this resolution then we shall confirm the results of Simpson et al 2015, who claimed that the SMGs are marginally resolved at 0.3 arcsec resolution and who claimed that their ~2kpc scale was consistent with bulge formation in a starburst. Thus 0.1 arcsec resolution is required to improve on the ALMA results of Simpson et al.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving high redshift sub-mm sources in ALESS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to measure the angular size of 15 sub-mm sources already detected using APEX LABOCA. The observations use ALMA band 7 and the C34-4 configuration to obtain observations with an angular resolution of 0."1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to observe in the same 850 micron (band 7), that we observed with LABOCA, such that we know the precise source flux and the S/N that we will achieve in our ALMA exposures. We propose to observe with the ALMA extended array in the C36-6 configuration to achieve 0.''1 resolution.
We show the coords and other parameters for each of the sources in Table 1 of our proposal. The positions for the WHDF EVLA detected sources and the ALESS sources are good to sub-arcsecond accuracy. The seven remaining unidentified WHDF sources have positions good to ~10'' from the LABOCA observations (Bielby et al 2011) and so will easily be detected within the ALMA primary beam-width, given our conservative exposure times proposed for the ALMA observations as described next.
Our faintest source has a flux of 3.2 mJy. For an extended source of ~1.5kpc, and our resolution scale of 0.''1 (~0.5kpc), this would give a mean flux per spatial resolution element of ~0.3mJy. Using the sensitivity calculator, we find that we can reach a 3-sigma sensitivity of 0.3 mJy per resolution element given a 5 min integration time with the C36-6 configuration (345 GHz observing frequency, 7.5 GHz bandwidth and default water vapour settings). The result is approximately the same for both our fields, with the Dec=-27deg field giving marginally better results. Alternatively, assuming a single point source, our faintest target at 3.2 mJy would have S/N~30.
For all 15 targets, we therefore require a total integration time of approximately 75 mins (excluding overheads, calibrations etc).
We request low-resolution continuum measurements of the targets, and therefore require no spectral mapping of the sources.

We request 0.1 arcsec ALMA resolution in order to achieve 0.5kpc/h resolution in a z~2 SMG. This resolution is crucial because it represents the smallest size that a dust torus around an AGN nucleus can be if it is to produce the ~35K dust temperatures shown by SMGs. If they are well resolved at this resolution then we shall confirm the results of Simpson et al 2015, who claimed that the SMGs are marginally resolved at 0.3 arcsec resolution and who claimed that their ~2kpc scale was consistent with bulge formation in a starburst. Thus 0.1 arcsec resolution is required to improve on the ALMA results of Simpson et al.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the hypothesis that bright sub-mm galaxies (SMGs) are powered by obscured AGN. We shall do this by measuring the angular size of 15 SMGs. 9 of these SMGs are X-ray quiet and form a complete sample from LABOCA observations of the William Herschel Deep Field (WHDF). The other 6 SMGs are identified with luminous absorbed X-ray QSOs at z~2, with 2 coming from the WHDF, supplemented by 4 from the Extended Chandra Deep Field South (ECDFS) ALESS. Our aim is to use exquisite ~0.1arcsec ALMA resolution to determine if any of these SMGs are still unresolved at our ~500pc resolution which is the expected size of AGN powered cool dust tori. The 6 X-ray quasars will also act as a control sample for the other 9 SMGs allowing a direct comparison of the resolvability between the two classes. If the SMGs are generally resolved then it would strongly suggest a star-forming origin for the sub-mm background. If the X-ray quiet SMGs are resolved and the X-ray loud are not then it will suggest SMGs comprise two different sub-populations, AGN- and star-formation dominated. This or any other outcome is guaranteed to reveal further the nature of the sub-mm and X-ray backgrounds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 0: A direct test of the AGN contribution to the high redshift Sub-mm population Cycle 1: Resolving AGN and SMGs - A `Rosetta Stone' for the X-ray and Sub-mm backgrounds Cycle 2: SMG dust heating - star-formation versus AGN via an ALMA high resolution survey
